Ratusan Petani Tembakau Jabar Tuntut Pemerintah Batalkan Kenaikan Cukai dan HJE Rokok
04 Nov 2019, 07:53 by Ai Rika Rachmawati
BANDUNG, (PR).- Ratusan Pertani Tembakau asal Cianjur, Ciamis, Banjar, Sumedang, Majalengka, Garut, Pangandaran, Bandung Barat, dan Kabupaten Bandung yang tergabung dalam Asosiasi Petani Tembakau Indonesia (APTI) Jawa Barat (Jabar), menggelar aksi demo di depan Kementrian Keuangan dan Istana Merdeka. Mereka mengajukan dua tuntutan. 
Ketua APTI Jabar, Suryana, mengatakan, tuntutan pertama mereka adalah pencabutan Peraturan Menteri Keuangan (PMK) No. 152/ 2019 tentang kenaikan cukai dan harga jual eceran (HJE) rokok. Sementara tututan kedua adalah Revisi PMK No.222 / PMK.07/ 2017 tentang penggunaan, pemanfaatan dana bagi hasil cukai hasil tembakau (DBH CHT) .
“Kami menolak PMK No. 152/ 2019. PMK tersebut berisi kenaikan cukai dan harga jual eceran rokok yang sangat tidak manusiawi dan sangat merugikan petani dan juga buruh di industri rokok dan tembakau," ujarnya, melalui siaran pers yang diterima "PR", Senin, 4 November 2019. 
Ia mengatakan, APTI Jabar ingin menuntut keadilan dari pemerintah. Menurut dia, kenaikan cukai rokok dan HJE rokok sebagaimana tertuang dalam PMK No. 152/2019 terlalu besar. 
"Kenakan cukai dan HJE tersebut akan menyebabkan berkurangnya pembelian tembakau hasil perkebunan masyarakat petani tembakau Jabar dan juga daerah daerah lainnya oleh para produsen rokok nasional," tuturnya.
Selain itu, menurut dia, tingginya harga jual rokok berpotensi menyebabkan semakin banyaknya rokok rokok illegal yang beredar di pasaran atau masyarakat. Hal itu bukan hanya akan merugikan masyarakat petani dan buruh industri rokok serta tembakau, tapi juga merugikan pemerintah. 
"Pemerintah akan kehilangan pendapatan dari cukai karena banyaknya rokok illegal," kata Suryana.
Kalaupun cukai dan HJE rokok harus naik, menurut dia, besarannya jangan sedrastis itu. Ia menilai, kenaikan harus dilakukan secara bertahap, misalnya untuk cukai periode pertama naik 10% dan periode kedua 7%.
"Jadi total 17%, begitu seterusnya. Kalau sekarang kan cukai naiknya 23%. Kenaikan di atas 20% itu terlalu drastis, sehingga mencekik produsen dan petani tembakau," kata Suryana.
Masyarakat Petani Tembakau Jabar, menurut dia, juga keberatan dengan kenaikan HJE yang berada di atas angka kewajaran, yakni 35 persen. Besaran kenaikannya lebih tinggi dari pada angka kenaikan cukai. 
Menurut Suryana, harusnya kenaikan HJE itu sebanding dengan besaran kenaikan cukai rokok. Jika kenaikan cukai rokok sebesar 10%, maka menurut dia, kenaikan HJE juga tidak lebih dari 10%. 
“Kenaikan HJE itu seharusnya seimbang dengan kenaikan cukai rokok. Selain itu diberlakukan bertahap, bukan sekaligus naik," tutur Suryana. 
Ia mengatakan, saat ini dampak dari kebijakan yang rencananya akan diberlakukan pada awal 2020 itu sudah dirasakan petani tembakau. Produsen rokok sudah mulai mengurangi pembelian tembakau hasil perkebunan para petani tembakau dari setiap daerah. 
"Hal ini amat meresahkan dan menyengsarakan petani tembakau. Pemerintah harus menyadari dan merasakan itu,” kata Suryana.
Sementara tuntutan kedua, yaitu revisi PMK No. 222/ PMK.07/2017 tentang Penggunaan, pemanfaatan, Pemantauan dan Evaluasi Dana Bagi Hasil Cukai Hasil Tembakau (DBHCHT). Dalam peraturan itu disebutkan penggunaan DBHCHT pengalokasiannya minimal 50 persen untuk kesehatan. 
“Kami meminta peraturan itu direvisi. Harusnya bukan minimal 50% untuk kesehatan melainkan maksimal 50% untuk kesehatan," katanya. 
Jika minimal 50% untuk kesehatan, menurut dia, bisa jadi keseluruhan dana DBHCHT untuk kesehatan. Padahal, ia menilai, masih banyak sektor lain yang harus menerima pemanfaatan dana DBHCHT. 
"Karena itu kami minta direvisi agar dana tersebut juga bisa dialokasikan untuk bidang lain yang juga bermanfaat untuk pembangunan masyarakat dan daerah penerima dan bagi hasil cukai dan tembakau,” kata Suryana.
Dalam PMK No. 222/ PMK.07/2017 Bab II Pasal 2  ayat 2 disebutkan penggunaan DBH CHT diprioritaskan untuk mendukung program jaminan kesehatan nasional paling sedikit sebesar 50% yang diterima dari setiap daerah. Sementara pada ayat 1 jyga disebutkan untuk peningkatan kualitas bahan baku, pembinaan industri, pembinaan lingkungan sosial, sosialisasi ketentuan di bidang cukai dan atau pemberantasan barang kena cukai illegal. 
"Pihak APTI Jabar meminta sektor lain selain kesehatan juga menjadi prioritas dari pemanfaatan DBH CHT tersebut. Kami berharap, pemerintah, khususnya kementrian keuangan, mendengarkan aspirasi kami," kata Suryana.***

Hundreds of West Java Tobacco Farmers Demand the Government to Cancel Excise and HJE Cigarette Increases
Nov 04 2019, 07:53 by Ai Rika Rachmawati
BANDUNG, (PR) .- Hundreds of Tobacco Farmers from Cianjur, Ciamis, Banjar, Sumedang, Majalengka, Garut, Pangandaran, West Bandung, and Bandung Regency who are members of the Indonesian Tobacco Farmers Association (APTI) in West Java (West Java), staged demonstrations in front of the Ministry of Finance and Merdeka Palace. They filed two demands.
West Java APTI Chairperson, Suryana, said their first demand was the revocation of Minister of Finance Regulation No. PMK. 152/2019 concerning the increase in excise tax and retail sale price (HJE) of cigarettes. While the second statement is the Revision of PMK No.222 / PMK.07 / 2017 concerning the use, utilization of revenue sharing funds for tobacco products (DBH CHT).
"We reject PMK No. 152 / 2019. The PMK contains an increase in excise tax and retail sale prices of cigarettes which are very inhumane and very detrimental to farmers and workers in the cigarette and tobacco industry, "he said, through a press release received by" PR ", Monday, November 4, 2019.
He said, APTI West Java wanted to demand justice from the government. According to him, the increase in cigarette excise tax and cigarette HJE as stated in PMK No. 152/2019 is too big.
"Wearing excise tax and HJE will cause a decrease in the purchase of tobacco plantations from tobacco farmers in West Java and other regions by national cigarette producers," he said.
In addition, according to him, the high selling price of cigarettes has the potential to cause more and more illegal cigarettes to circulate in the market or the public. This will not only harm the farming community and the cigarette and tobacco industry workers, but also the government.
"The government will lose revenue from excise due to the large number of illegal cigarettes," Suryana said.
Even if excise tax and HJE cigarettes have to go up, according to him, the amount should not be that drastic. He considered, the increase should be done in stages, for example for excise tax the first period rose 10% and the second period 7%.
"So the total is 17%, and so on. Now the excise tax is 23% increase. The increase above 20% is too drastic, so it is choking tobacco producers and farmers," Suryana said.
West Java Tobacco Farmers Society, according to him, also objected to the increase in HJE which is above the fairness rate, which is 35 percent. The magnitude of the increase is higher than the rate of increase in excise.
According to Suryana, the HJE increase should be proportional to the amount of the cigarette tax increase. If the cigarette excise tax increases by 10%, then according to him, the increase in HJE is also no more than 10%.
"The increase in HJE should be balanced with an increase in cigarette excise duty. In addition, it will be implemented in stages, not at the same time, "said Suryana.
He said, currently the impact of the policy planned to be implemented in early 2020 has been felt by tobacco farmers. Cigarette producers have begun to reduce purchases of tobacco plantations from tobacco farmers from each region.
"This is very disturbing and miserable for tobacco farmers. The government must realize and feel it," said Suryana.
While the second demand, namely revision of PMK No. 222 / PMK.07 / 2017 concerning the Use, Utilization, Monitoring and Evaluation of Tobacco Product Profit Sharing Funds (DBHCHT). In the regulation mentioned the use of DBHCHT allocation of at least 50 percent for health.
"We ask that the regulation be revised. It should not be at least 50% for health but a maximum of 50% for health, "he said.
If at least 50% is for health, according to him, it could be the entire DBHCHT fund for health. In fact, he considered, there are still many other sectors that must receive DBHCHT fund utilization.
"Therefore, we ask to be revised so that the funds can also be allocated to other fields which are also beneficial for the development of communities and receiving areas and for the sharing of excise and tobacco," Suryana said.
In PMK No. 222 / PMK.07 / 2017 Chapter II Article 2 paragraph 2 states that the use of the CHH DBH is prioritized to support the national health insurance program of at least 50% received from each region. While in paragraph 1 jyga is mentioned to improve the quality of raw materials, industrial development, social environment development, socialization of provisions in the field of excise and or eradication of goods subject to illegal excise.
"The West Java APTI requested other sectors besides health to be a priority for the utilization of the CHH DBH. We hope that the government, especially the finance ministry, will listen to our aspirations," said Suryana. ***
